This guy's writing optimizes what I always believed a chalkboard should sound like when coming in contact with chalk.  My favorite math teacher in high school thus far, even though he is the only teacher I am incapable of directly interacting with.
I'm studying online and the videos they have are either non existent or poor quality.  These lectures make my education much more engaging than it otherwise would be.

Thank you MIT OCW and Prof. Auroux for these lectures. And especially for the elegant way to define the always tricky differential notation. You are the best. Best wishes from Chile.

The course textbook is: Edwards, Henry C., and David E. Penney. Multivariable Calculus. 6th ed. Lebanon, IN: Prentice Hall, 2002. ISBN: 9780130339676. See http://ocw.mit.edu/18-02F07​ for more info. We also recommend you check out the Scholar version of the course: http://ocw.mit.edu/18-02SCF10. It has more materials for the self-learner. Best wishes on your studies!
